words and phrases to english.gripping: exciting or interesting in a way that keeps your attention
words and phrases to english.remarkable [rɪˈmɑːkəbl]: unusual or surprising in a way that causes people to take notice

words and phrases to english.unprecedented: that has never happened, been done or been known before
words and phrases to english.exploit [ɪkˈsplɔɪt]: to treat a person or situation as an opportunity to gain an advantage for yourself
words and phrases to english.scrupulous [ˈskruːpjələs]: careful about paying attention to every detail
words and phrases to english.zeitgeist [ˈzaɪtɡaɪst]: the general mood or quality of a particular period of history, as shown by the ideas, beliefs, etc. common at the time
words and phrases to english.welfare [ˈwelfeə(r)]: the general health, happiness and safety of a person, an animal or a group
words and phrases to english.cyclical [ˈsaɪklɪkal]: repeated many times and always happening in the same order
words and phrases to english.impose [ɪmˈpəʊz]: to introduce a new law, rule, tax, etc.
words and phrases to english.blatant [ˈbleɪtnt]: (of actions that are considered bad) done in an obvious and open way without caring if people are shocked
words and phrases to english.Modest [ˈmɒdɪst]: not very large, expensive, important, etc.
words and phrases to english.Carnival [ˈkɑːnɪvl]: a public festival, usually one that happens at a regular time each year, that involves music and dancing in the streets, for which people wear brightly coloured clothes
words and phrases to english.ceiling [ˈsiːlɪŋ]: the top inside surface of a room
words and phrases to english.vary [ˈveəri]: to be different from each other in size, shape, etc.
words and phrases to english.wafer [ˈweɪfə(r)]: a thin, light biscuit, often eaten with ice cream
words and phrases to english.dough: a mixture of flour, water, etc. that is made into bread and pastry
words and phrases to english.festival: a day or period of the year when people stop working to celebrate a special event, often a religious one OR a series of performances of music, plays, films, etc., usually organized in the same place once a year
words and phrases to english.Outburst [ˈaʊtbɜːst/]: a sudden strong expression of an emotion
words and phrases to english.prevalent [ˈprevələnt]: dominant, common | that exists or is very common at a particular time or in a particular place
words and phrases to english.refugee: a person who has been forced to leave their country or home, because there is a war or for political, religious or social reasons
words and phrases to english.resulted in: to make something happen / having caused
words and phrases to english.authority: the power to give orders to people
words and phrases to english.minority: the smaller part of a group

words and phrases to english.sharpen [ˈʃɑːpən]: to become or make something better, more effective, etc.
words and phrases to english.work smth out: to calculate something, to find the answer to something
words and phrases to english.put off: to make somebody dislike somebody/something or not trust them/it OR to cancel a meeting or an arrangement that you have made with somebody
words and phrases to english.oust: to force somebody out of a job or position of power, especially in order to take their place
words and phrases to english.meritles: worthless or lacking some or all of the legal or substantive elements required to have a prospect of success

words and phrases to english.accusation: a statement saying that you think a person is guilty of doing something wrong or illegal
words and phrases to english.urge: to advise or try hard to persuade somebody to do something | to recommend something strongly
words and phrases to english.compensation [ˌkɒmpenˈseɪʃn]: something, especially money, that somebody gives you because they have hurt you, or damaged something that you own
words and phrases to english.devolve [dɪˈvɒlv]: To delegate (a responsibility, duty, etc.) on or upon someone
words and phrases to english.beseech: to ask somebody for something in an anxious way because you want or need it very much
words and phrases to english.disdain: the feeling that somebody/something is not good enough to deserve your respect or attention
words and phrases to english.persecute: to treat somebody in a cruel and unfair way, especially because of their race, religion or political beliefs
words and phrases to english.deposit: a sum of money that is given as the first part of a larger payment
words and phrases to english.similes: a word or phrase that compares something to something else, using the words like or as, for example a face like a mask or as white as snow
words and phrases to english.diligent: showing care and effort in your work or duties
words and phrases to english.instalment: one of a number of payments that are made regularly over a period of time until something has been paid for
words and phrases to english.skunk: a small black and white North American animal that can produce a strong unpleasant smell to defend itself when it is attacked

words and phrases to english.perceive: to understand or think of somebody/something in a particular way
words and phrases to english.prejudice: an unreasonable dislike of or preference for a person, group, custom, etc., especially when it is based on their race, religion, sex, etc.

words and phrases to english.contempt: the feeling that somebody/something is without value and deserves no respect at all
words and phrases to english.elation [ɪˈleɪʃn]: a feeling of great happiness and excitement
words and phrases to english.oversee: watching smbd if job is done right

words and phrases to english.to emerge: to move out of smth and become possible to be seen

words and phrases to english.commodity: product/raw material that can be bought/sold
words and phrases to english.to become disillusioned: to become disappointed and unhappy because of discovering the truth about something or someone that you liked
words and phrases to english.obesity [əʊˈbiːsəti/]: the quality or fact of being very fat, in a way that is not healthy

words and phrases to english.to flourish [ˈflʌrɪʃ]: to develop quickly and become successful or common

words and phrases to english.dining in the dark: eating while not being able to see anything

words and phrases to english.to spill out: to tell somebody all about a problem etc. very quickly; to come out quickly
words and phrases to english.stallholder: a person who sells things from a stall in a market, etc.

words and phrases to english.breadth: width/the distance or measurement from one side to the other; how broad or wide something is

words and phrases to english.withstand: to be strong enough not to be hurt or damaged by extreme conditions, the use of force, etc
words and phrases to english.disruptive [dɪsˈrʌptɪv]: causing problems, noise, etc. so that something cannot continue normally
words and phrases to english.thrive [θraɪv]: to become, and continue to be, successful, strong, healthy, etc.
words and phrases to english.gross [ɡrəʊs]: to earn a particular amount of money before tax has been taken off it

words and phrases to english.helm: a handle or wheel used for controlling the direction in which a boat or ship moves
words and phrases to english.bow: to move your head or the top half of your body forwards and downwards as a sign of respect or to say hello or goodbye
words and phrases to english.overhaul [ˈəʊvəhɔːl]: an examination of a machine or system, including doing repairs on it or making changes to it
words and phrases to english.opaque [əʊˈpeɪk]: (of glass, liquid, etc.) not clear enough to see through or allow light through
words and phrases to english.perpendicular [ˌpɜːpənˈdɪkjələ(r)]: forming an angle of 90° with another line or surface

words and phrases to english.agenda [əˈdʒendə]: a list of items to be discussed at a meeting
words and phrases to english.laid-back [ˌleɪd ˈbæk]: calm and relaxed; seeming not to worry about anything
words and phrases to english.hospitable: (of a person) pleased to welcome guests; generous and friendly to visitors
